The processes that we've historically used to connect large loads are not providing the clarity or the certainty that's needed for developers. So we've made improvements to those processes. What we're fundamentally dealing with here today is an optimization problem that's needed over the next several years. Because the solution long term is the development of infrastructure that's going to be able to serve the needs of these large loads over time. And that process is underway. We've already seen a significant amount of transmission being proposed in order to meet that. Our large load forecast anticipates the loads that are coming into the state and has put forth RTPs and plans in order to address and build towards that. However, the pace at which that infrastructure can be built is generally longer slower than what we can see developing on the large loads that are coming to the state. So there is an interim period of time where we have to manage how to connect those large loads in a reliable way and do so expeditiously. And in a way that optimizes the capacity that is on the grid today because there is a lot of capacity on the RACOT grid. We see most of the hours of the of the year. There's plenty of capacity for growth to connect. So we want to optimize bringing resources into that while the grid is upgraded and infrastructure is built. So one of the key one of the key issues that we deal with and that we're having to address is a fact that transmission when it gets when a study is done with regards to the transmission capacity for a project to connect when that study is completed. And then the project is ready to begin moving forward with signing power contracts and developing their assets. Veterans mission capacity does not get reserved or committed for that resource. Our current process effectively studies the system as it is that point in time and with the known developments that are in front of us. But then because of the changes that we're seeing that are so significant that the volume being so high within three six months. The circumstances at that approved location on the grid at a future point in time now is different. And so without holding that capacity for a project what can happen is over time. Pancaking projects in the similar areas of the grid are creating a need to go back, re-study and re-confirm, re-evaluate the capability to serve those loads. Introducing uncertainty and a lack of clarity as to where a customer actually is in the process. And so when you consider the size, the volume, the dollars that are being invested in these kinds of projects, it's really an untenable process to continue with that approach. So that's one of the key issues. I think of it almost a little bit like a restaurant analogy where somebody calls or caught the restaurant and says, you know, we're going to come tonight for dinner at seven o'clock. And we say great, we've got a table available. But then between now and seven o'clock, 10 other people come in because we don't have a reservation system and the tables are gone. And so that's effectively the way the transmission study process works today. There is no commitment or holding of that reservation effectively for the customer. So where we think we need to go in order to deal with this is looking at a process that we're calling a batch process. And a batch effectively is going to be in a group of projects that are ready to be studied. We'll all get studied together. And then that established set of results in terms of the transmission needs and capacity to serve those will be essentially locked in for that group of customers. And that'll create a foundation and a baseline for building forward the next batch that would occur. We need to start with a batch zero concept in order to begin this process because we have a lot of projects that are in the queue today. And we need to establish that first set foundation that we can then hold and commit that transmission for all of those projects. And then in each subsequent batch, we would then build on the assumptions that have changed between now and then, which includes added infrastructure as well as added loads. And so we think that a batch process would best serve and be able to support getting clarity and transparency to developers as well as to transmission operators and other stakeholders in the state as to how we can support and serve the growth that's coming our way. We think timing is a really important part of this. And so there's clearly a pressure to move quickly and support the economic growth that's coming our way. And so we would propose to try to set up this batch zero construct sometime in the first quarter of 2026 if possible so that we can get that that foundational establishment of projects and the transmission that there's going to be committed to serve them so that then subsequent projects can be evaluated against that. So we're going to have to work on which I think is going to be one of the more complex elements of this is establishing what's the criteria for inclusion into that batch. And so we're going to have to look at characteristics of the projects as they are underway today, determine which ones have the highest likelihood of developing because again we're committing transmission capacity. So we only want to study and hold capacity for people that are actually going to show up at the restaurant for dinner, not those that are just thinking maybe they want to come or maybe they don't. And so that's a really important criteria for the first step as well as subsequent steps. We could be looking at criteria that includes financial security in order to show the seriousness of the development. So people would be to run a batch study more than once a year.
